post_text:
Weatherford ISD's Kids Unite offers an all-day summer camp program for students ages 5-14 years old. (Child must be 5 prior to attending). The weekly camps are available from 7:00 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. Campers get breakfast, lunch, an afternoon snack, daily swim, a camp t-shirt, and a weekly field trip all for one low price. There is a one time enrollment fee per family for the summer to cover supplies.

KU Camp Staff is American Red Cross First Aid and CPR certified, screened through WISD criminal history checks, and selected for their maturity, patience, experience, and ability to work with children.

For more information, including the weekly schedule of activities, visit https://bit.ly/2J7yqeM .

Weatherford ISD Notice for Horseshoe Bend Families:

For the safety of our students and bus drivers, and in anticipation of further flooding, Weatherford ISD will implement the following bus route changes for the Horseshoe Bend neighborhood beginning on Monday morning (May 6) and continuing until further notice.

Horseshoe Bend pick up at Club House ‚Ä™Monday morning‚Ä¨.

Bus 21 ‚Ä™6:15 - 6:30‚Ä¨
Bus 23 ‚Ä™6:20 - 6:40‚Ä¨
Bus 48 ‚Ä™5:35 - 5:40‚Ä¨

Drop off times are ‚Ä™4:30‚Ä¨ for elementary and ‚Ä™5:00‚Ä¨ for secondary.

Weatherford ISD encourages our families to also monitor local news stations for the most current road conditions, avoid walking or driving into high water, and follow instructions issued by emergency personnel.

post_text:
Yesterday, we discovered a small cluster of honeybees in a live oak tree just outside an entrance to Weatherford High School. The bees were very active, especially as students walked by the tree, and posed a safety concern for students, staff, and guests who might be allergic to their venom.

The decline in the honeybee population has been widely reported, so when our Maintenance Department was notified of the beehive, they opted to contact a beekeeper rather than use an extermination process.

Our sincere thanks to Jason Smith of JC‚Äôs Honey Bees for working with WISD‚Äôs Facility Coordinator, Bob Bridges to remove and relocate the beehive at no cost to the District. This situation was resolved in a timely manner, keeping a safe entrance to the high school! #WhyWISD

Severe weather season is here and we want to make sure you are prepared. Here are some safety tips to consider anytime storms are in the forecast. We also want to reassure you that when there is a threat of severe weather we will be monitoring the conditions to ensure the safety of our students and staff.

post_text:
With this afternoon's forecast calling for thunderstorms, lightning, and hail, please be assured that Weatherford ISD‚Äôs Safety and Security department will closely monitor weather conditions throughout the day.

Weatherford ISD subscribes to Perry Weather, a service that includes access to a meteorologist for our area. We also follow the weather on local media stations and use several weather apps.

While we don‚Äôt expect these storms to affect dismissal at this time, we will implement safety processes for severe weather warnings, if needed.

Should it become necessary to communicate with parents this afternoon regarding the weather, we will use the SchoolMessenger notification system to send calls/emails/texts to parents. Information will also be communicated on the Weatherford ISD website, and WISD social media sites - Facebook and Twitter.

We appreciate your support as we work to ensure the safety of our students, parents, and staff.

post_text:
School Safety Reminders

As warmer weather arrives, many of our students will be walking, riding a bike, or skateboarding to school. We ask that drivers:

- Observe all school zones.
- Watch for children who may step into roadways when traveling near schools, especially on roads where there are no sidewalks.
- Obey all traffic laws related to school buses. State law requires that drivers stop when a bus is stopped to load or unload students.

We also want to take this opportunity to remind our families and students of our Roos Eyes Open process and have created a video that explains the process of anonymously reporting tips through Parker County Crime Stoppers.

This afternoon a semi truck negotiated a turn near the QT on Bowie Drive and clipped the side view mirror of Bus 24. There were no injuries sustained as a result of this minor accident.

Students riding on this bus have been transferred to Bus 23 and the Transportation department is in the process of notifying parents.

We are most grateful that our students, bus driver, and the semi truck driver were not injured. Parents should be prepared for students to arrive home a little later than normal.

post_text:
Phoenix Construction presented the High Five Award to two outstanding staff members yesterday!

Kendall Berry - Austin Elementary
Kendall goes above and beyond every day to help students reach their full academic potential. She is the Instructional Interventionist at Austin Elementary where she helps teachers plan, implement, and inspect instruction in their classroom. Kendall is a life-long learner with a passion for helping everyone she meets.

Lacey Fliger - Curtis Elementary
Lacey goes above and beyond in her role as librarian. She leads the Student Leadership Team and runs our STEAM club after school. She promotes and instills a love of reading to all students and is often seen after the school in the bus room helping students continue their learning.

Congratulations to Kendall Berry and Lacey Fliger!
text:
Phoenix Construction presented the High Five Award to two outstanding staff members yesterday!

Kendall Berry - Austin Elementary
Kendall goes above and beyond every day to help students reach their full academic potential. She is the Instructional Interventionist at Austin Elementary where she helps teachers plan, implement, and inspect instruction in their classroom. Kendall is a life-long learner with a passion for helping everyone she meets.

Lacey Fliger - Curtis Elementary
Lacey goes above and beyond in her role as librarian. She leads the Student Leadership Team and runs our STEAM club after school. She promotes and instills a love of reading to all students and is often seen after the school in the bus room helping students continue their learning.

Congratulations to Kendall Berry and Lacey Fliger!
